entry.name: UNAVCO GNSS Glossary
entry.description: This is an example glossary to demonstrate RAMADDA's glossary facility. The content was originally taken from UNAVCO's GNSS Glossary.

entry.name: 4-character ID
entry.description:
four printable ASCII characters (usually case-insensitive alphanumeric plus underscore) which traditionally have been used to designate a [[monument]] or [[site]], so with a-z, 0-9, and _ there are 37^4 = 1874161 unique 4-character IDs possible; see also
  • [[monument code]]
  • [[visit code]]
  • [[raw file code]]
in the best documented cases, the monument code, visit code, and raw file code are identical, though in some cases the documentation ([[form]], etc.) and the [[raw data]] files may indicate different 4-character IDs even though all information is for the same [[survey point]] of a [[monument]]

entry.name: antenna
entry.description:
(for the [[GNSS]] community:) a resonant device that detects the GHz [[GPS]], [[GLONASS]], [[Galileo]], or [[SBAS]] microwave [[signal]] and converts them to electrical signals for processing by a GNSS [[receiver]]; see also text documentation:
  • Galileo Open Service Signal In Space Interface Control Document (OS SIS ICD, Draft 0)
  • IGS standard antennae dimensions (new)
  • IGS standard antennae dimensions (old)
and other:
  • GPS antenna calibrations by the staff of the Instrumentation and Methodologies Branch, Geodetic Services Division, National Geodetic Survey, NOAA, Dept. of Commerce
for more information

entry.name: antenna cable
entry.description: <wiki> a 50-ohm impedence, RF-shielded, co-axial cable used to connect the [[antenna]] to the [[receiver]]

entry.name: antenna dome or radome
entry.description: a thin, almost microwave-transparent material placed over a [[GNSS]] [[antenna]], often in the shape (or nearly so) of a simple geometrical surface (e.g. hemisphere, cone, paraboloid, etc.); use of an antenna dome slightly alters the effective [[phase center]] of the antenna for high-precision geodetic positioning due the dielectric contact of the dome and the dome's geometry relative to the true phase centers of the antenna, thus requiring the exact type of dome used to be known (see dome designations at end of IGS Central Bureau receiver & antenna table)

entry.name: antenna height
entry.description: <wiki> vertical distance from the [[survey point]] of a [[monument]] to the [[antenna reference point]] (ARP) of the [[antenna]]; this may be calculated using the geometry of the antenna and the antenna slant height

entry.name: antenna orientation
entry.description: <wiki> the [[antenna]] is usually rotated into a standard orientation, often so that the [[antenna cable]] connector is toward geographic north, though often in the field only the local magnetic north direction is known, requiring the local [[magnetic declination]] to be known

entry.name: antenna reference point
entry.description:
or ARP; an established point on the [[antenna]] [[choke ring]], ground plane, or base from which the L1 and L2 [[phase center]] are measured; see also text documentation:
  • IGS standard antennae dimensions (new)
  • IGS standard antennae dimensions (old)
for more information

entry.name: Archive Database
entry.description: <wiki> a relational database management system (RBDMS) used by the UNAVCO Boulder Facility Data Group to track and retrieve archived [[data file]] and [[metadata]]; uses Oracle engine

entry.name: Archive process
entry.description:
the steps undertaken to archive [[GNSS]] [[data]], [[log]], and/or other [[form]] at the [[UNAVCO]] Boulder Facility Archive, which roughly are:
  1. taking receipt of incoming data and or logs, whether by physical media or by electronic transfer and this receipt entered in the [[Archive Database]]; the physical media (or tape copies for electronic transfers) are stored in the [[Physical Repository]]; this step is referred to as data/log check-in;
  2. extracting [[metadata]] about the received data files and entering this information into the Archive Database; the data files are compressed and copied into the [[On-line Repository]]; the data files handled in this way can be [[raw data]] or [[RINEX]] or some combination of the two (though a copy of the raw data is always desired at a minimum); this step is referred to as data injection;
  3. the [[visit]] metadata is extracted from the logs and entered into the Archive Database;
  4. and finally the visits are associated with the injected data, often requiring a reexamination of the metadata of the visits and of the data in order to resolve discrepancies; this step is referred to as validation
although the exact steps vary on a case by case basis

entry.name: ARGO
entry.description: "Automated Reformatter of GPS Observations"; both the software and the resulting fixed-format ASCII exchange representation of GPS [[data]] and [[metadata]], similar to [[RINEX]], created and made available by the National Geodetic Survey, U.S. Department of Commerce

entry.name: ARP
entry.description: antenna reference point

entry.name: BARD
entry.description:
"Bay Area Regional Deformation" Northern California Continuous GPS Network; see also:
  • BARD homepage
for more information

entry.name: BDT
entry.description: "BeiDou Time"; analogous to GPS time, the time in seconds, skipping [[UTC]] [[leap second]], since 1.0 Jan 2006 UTC — therefore an offset from GPST of 1356 weeks of exactly 604800 seconds each

entry.name: Beidou-1 Navigation System
entry.description: a specific spaceborne radionavigation system financed and to be operated by the People's Republic of China, Phase I, consisting of 3 validation geosynchronous satellites (launches of BD-1A — no longer in use — on 30 Oct 2000 UTC, BD-1B on 20 Dec 2000 UTC, BD-1C on 24 May 2003 UTC, and BD-1D on 2 Feb 2007 UTC); see Encyclopedia Astronautica: Beidou)

entry.name: Beidou-2 Navigation System
entry.description:
also known as Compass: a specific spaceborne radionavigation system financed and to be operated by the People's Republic of China to be completed in two phases: Phase II (planned to be completed by 2012) to consist of 14 satellites: 5 of which will be in geostationary (GEO) orbit, 5 in inclined geosynchronous orbit (IGSO), and 4 in [[MEO]] — broadcasting 5 signals; Phase III (planned to be completed by 2020) to consist of 35 satellites: 5 of which will be in geostationary (GEO) orbit, 3 in inclined geosynchronous orbit (IGSO), and 27 in [[MEO]] — broadcasting 10 signals; the [[MEO]] SVs will have orbits with about 55-56° inclinations and be approximately 21540 km above the Earth (orbital period of 12h 53m, or 13 orbits every 7 [[sidereal day]]); using code-division multiple access with right-hand circularly polarized carriers centered at:

Phase II:
    B1 = 1561.098 MHz
    B3 = 1268.52 MHz
    B2 = 1207.14 MHz
Phase III:
    B1 = 1575.42 MHz
    B3 = 1268.52 MHz
    B2 = 1191.795 MHz
Beidou-2 will use [[BDT]] (Compass/Beidou Time) as the time standard and [[CGCS2000]] as the spatial reference frame. Originally planned as a purely military system, China announced on 2 Nov 2006 that in 2008 a free open service would allow civilian use with position accuracy of 10 meters, clock synchronization to an accuracy of 50 ns, and speeds to within 0.2 m/s; launches to populate the MEO portion have been: BD-2A (M1) on 13 Apr 2007 UTC; launches to populate the GEO portion have been: BD-2G (G2) on 14 Apr 2009 UTC, Beidou DW3 (G1) on 16 Jan 2010 UTC; see Encyclopedia Astronautica: Beidou)

entry.name: BINEX
entry.description:
"Bininary Exchange"; binary exchange representation of [[GNSS]] [[data]] and [[metadata]] which allows for encapsulation all or most of the information currently exchanged with the ASCII formats of [[RINEX]], [[SINEX]], [[IONEX]], [[SP3]], and so on as various BINEX records are defined; see also:
  • BINEX homepage
for more information

entry.name: calendar
entry.description:
calendars from 1980 - 2019 showing the [[day-of-year]] ([[ordinal date]]) and [[GPS week]]. On each calendar for each week, the day-of-year is on the left in square brackets [ddd] for the first day of the given week and month, and the GPS week in on the right in pointy brackets <wwww>.
     1980 1981 1982 1983 1984 1985 1986 1987 1988 1989
     1990 1991 1992 1993 1994 1995 1996 1997 1998 1999
     2000 2001 2002 2003 2004 2005 2006 2007 2008 2009
     2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019

entry.name: campaign
entry.description: <wiki> a well-defined number of [[visit]] to a group of geographically- or scientifically-related [[monument]] over a well-defined time interval, typically several months in length

entry.name: campaign data
entry.description: <wiki> [[data]] from one or more [[site]] from a [[campaign]]

entry.name: CBIS
entry.description: [[IGS]] "Central Bureau Information System"

entry.name: CDDIS
entry.description:
"Crustal Dynamics Data Information System" of NASA; see also:
  • CDDIS homepage

entry.name: CGCS2000
entry.description: "China Geodetic Coordinate System 2000"; spatial reference system of [[Beidou-1]] and [[Beidou-2]]; consistent with [[ITRF]]

entry.name: choke ring
entry.description: <wiki> concentric rings of metal around and below the ground plane of the [[antenna]], perhaps separated by microwave-absorbing foam, for the purpose of reducing multipath effects produced by the local geometry of the antenna relative to the [[site]]

entry.name: Compass
entry.description: <wiki> see [[Beidou-2]]

entry.name: continuous data
entry.description: <wiki> [[data]] from a [[continuous site]]

entry.name: continuous monitoring
entry.description: <wiki> round-the-clock receiver collection of [[data]] at a [[setup]]/[[station]], probably at a regular sampling interval

entry.name: continuous site
entry.description: <wiki> a [[site]] at which [[continuous monitoring]] is occurring for one or more [[monument]]

entry.name: continuous station
entry.description: <wiki> one [[permanent station]] at a [[continuous site]]

entry.name: contract
entry.description: <wiki> the legal agreement to fund a [[project]]

entry.name: Coordinated Universal Time
entry.description: <wiki> see [[UTC]]

entry.name: CORS
entry.description:
"Continuously Operating Reference Station" network of NOAA's National Geodetic Survey; see also:
  • CORS homepage
  • CORS Station Guidelines

entry.name: country
entry.description: <wiki> a geo-political region, e.g. Antarctica, Chile, Russia, USA, etc.

entry.name: data
entry.description:
(one of several possible meanings depending on context:)
  1. information that can be used to reconstruct [[GNSS]] [[observable]] or a representation of the observables themselves produced by a GNSS [[receiver]], otherwise known as "observation data";
  2. observation data plus any of a variety of related ancillary data collected by a GNSS receiver, e.g. navigation data (SV-broadcast orbit information), meteorological or other geophysical data (collected at the [[site]] and input to the receiver, such as air temperature, air pressure, air relative humidity, earth tilt, earth strain, etc.);
  3. any output from a GNSS receiver, especially [[raw data]];
  4. any format in addition to raw data which endeavors to preserve the information content of raw data from a GNSS receiver necessary for processing, e.g. [[FICA]], [[ARGO]], [[RINEX]]

entry.name: data file
entry.description: <wiki> (a bit of a misnomer since:) persistent storage on [[media]] of at least [[GNSS]] [[data]] (observation data, navigation data, associated meteorological data, and/or other possible data types), and usually also associated [[metadata]], where the data is generally grouped into a time window for a specific [[antenna]]/[[receiver]] combination for a specific [[survey point]]; e.g. a typical [[raw data]] file or [[RINEX]] file; the metadata in a data file is always treated as suspect until verified by information on a [[log]]

entry.name: data format
entry.description: <wiki> [[data]] recorded in one of a number of manufacturers' [[raw data]] specifications, or in [[BINEX]], [[RINEX]], [[RTCM]] 2.3 or 3.0, [[ARGO]], [[FICA]], or one of a number of other possible specifications

entry.name: data-logging
entry.description: <wiki> [[data]] from a [[GNSS]] [[receiver]] is streamed in near real-time, usually via serial RS-232, to a device (the "data-logger") which stores the data on [[media]] and/or in random access memory (RAM)

entry.name: data set
entry.description: <wiki> the second-highest level of organization of [[data]] at the UNAVCO Boulder Facility Archive, with one or more data set with each [[group]]; the data set allows division by when the [[data]] and [[form]] were deposited and who deposited them, [[media]] information, whether the data in the data set is public or not, and a notes area

entry.name: datum
entry.description: <wiki> a set of constants specifying a coordinate system used for geodetic control; if a datum is modeled on a reference ellipsoid of revolution (such as [[WGS-84]]), then 8 constants are needed to specify a complete datum, e.g. 3 to specify the origin, 3 to specify the orientation of the coordinate system, and 2 to specify the dimensions of the ellipsoid

entry.name: datum transformation
entry.description: a mathematical transformation between two [[datum]], some of which are the 7-parameter Helmert transformation, the 5-parameter Molodensky or 3-parameter Abridged Molodensky transformations, the 10-parameter (7+3) Molodensky-Badekas transformation; see datum transformations and coordinate conversions and transformations including formulas

entry.name: day-of-year
entry.description: <wiki> sometimes incorrectly called the [[Julian day]], the day-of-year is a sequential numbering of the days of the year such that Jan 1 is day-of-year 1, Jan 2 is day-of-year 2, ending with Dec 31 being day-of-year 365 in non-leap years and day-of-year 366 in leap years; also called the [[ordinal date]]; see also [[calendar]]

entry.name: DCB
entry.description: see "differential code bias"

entry.name: differential code bias
entry.description:
[[SV]] or [[receiver]] time-dependent correction to pseudocode [[observable]] of [[GNSS]] data, agreed upon by the [[IGS]] to modify data from older receivers to be compatible with newer generation receivers, where typically older [[GPS]]-capable receivers used cross correlation to determine the P-code when antispoofing was activated on the GPS SV; see also:
  • IGSMAIL-2744
  • cc2noncc.f code
  • p1c1bias.hist: bias history file for cc2noncc
  • AIUB's CODE DCB archive
  • MIT GAMIT/GLOBE-K rcvant.dat

entry.name: dome
entry.description: <wiki> see [[antenna dome]]

entry.name: DOMES number
entry.description: world-wide unique designation for a particular monument assigned by [[IERS]]; application for a DOMES number for a [[permanent station]] (for SLR, VLBI, DORIS, GPS, etc.) is made to the IERS TRF section using the DOMES request form

entry.name: download
entry.description: <wiki> a defined protocol transaction between a [[receiver]] and computer to obtain one or more [[data file]] stored in the receiver for a completed set of [[GNSS]] measurement [[epoch]] (compare with [[data-logging]])

entry.name: EarthScope
entry.description:
earth science initiative in the USA with funding (proposed) from FY2003 - FY2012 to investigate the structure and evolution of the North American continent and the physical processes controlling earthquakes and volcanic eruptions; see also:
  • EarthScope homepage
  • SAFOD (deep drilling component)
  • PBO (geodetic component)
  • USArray (seismic component)

entry.name: ECEF
entry.description: "Earth-centered, Earth-fixed"

entry.name: email
entry.description: <wiki> "electronic mail"; see [[smtp]]

entry.name: epoch
entry.description: <wiki> a specific time instance using either the [[GPS time]] basis, [[GLONASS time]] basis, or Galileo system time

entry.name: FICA
entry.description: "Floating Integer Character ASCII"; ASCII exchange representation of GPS [[data]] and [[metadata]] developed by the Applied Research Laboratory of the University of Texas, Austin which preserves all the information found in the [[raw data]] from various [[receiver]]

entry.name: form
entry.description:
one of the documents to record [[metadata]] about a [[campaign]], a [[site]], a [[monument]], a [[antenna]], a [[receiver]], a [[visit]], or installation of a [[continuous site]]; a standardized form for any of the above is made available by the UNAVCO Boulder Facility Data Group; see forms for:
  • Survey log — Monument Visit Logsheet
  • Continuous Site Installation Report

entry.name: ftp
entry.description: "file transfer protocol"; used for pulling (getting) or pushing (putting) ASCII or binary files between two nodes on a TCP/IP network; if set up, can be either be anonymous or via a user account

entry.name: Galileo
entry.description:
a specific spaceborne radionavigation system financed and to be operated by ESA (European Space Agency) to consist of 27 satellites with 3 active on-orbit spares arranged in three [[MEO]] orbital planes at 56° inclination, approximately 23616 km above the Earth (orbital period of 14h 22m, or 5 orbits every 3 [[sidereal day]]), using code-division multiple access with right-hand circularly polarized carriers centered at E2-L1-E1 = 1575.42 MHz, E5a = 1176.45 MHz, E5b = 1207.14 MHz, and E6 = 1278.75 MHz; will develop and use its own time standard and own spatial reference ellipsoid frame; the Galileo constellation should be operational some time in the early 21st century; in-orbit valiation elements GIOVE-A and -B launched in Dec 2005 and Apr 2008; the second phase of In-Orbit Validation (IOV) satellites are now planned for launch starting in 2011; the unclassified user interface of which is defined in the [[OS SIS ICD]]: Galileo Open Service Signal-In-Space Interface Control Document; see also
  • GIOVE — first phase: definition (Galileo In-Orbit Validation Element)
  • IOV — second phase: development (In-Orbit Validation)
  • FOC — final phase: Full Operations Capability
  • Galileo — European Satellite Navigation System (quick overview of Galileo)
  • Status of Galileo Frequency and Signal Design
  • Galileo Mission High Level Definition

entry.name: GBAS
entry.description:
"Ground Based Agmentation System"; a set of ground transponders to augment [[GNSS]] use for civilian applications, which includes:
  • [[LAAS]] (Local Area Augmentation System)
see also:
  • GNSS Augmentation: Ground Based Augmentation System

entry.name: geocode
entry.description:
a published GHAM geocode definition is pending, but roughly speaking this is a even-byte, big-endian alphanumeric code which specifies the latitude and longitude to a certain precision; each two bytes specifies a certain level, where e.g. on the Earth:
  • Level 4 (8 characters) delineate a region approximately 480 meters on each side
  • Level 6 (12 characters) delineate a region approximately 1.9 meters on each side
  • Level 8 (16 characters) delineate a region approximately 1 mm on each side

entry.name: GLONASS
entry.description: "Global Navigation Satellite System"; a specific spaceborne radionavigation system financed and operated by the Soviet Commonwealth planned to consist of 21 satellites with 3 active on-orbit spares arranged in three [[MEO]] orbital planes at 64.8° inclination, approximately 19130 km above the Earth (orbital period of 11h 16m, or 17 orbits every 8 [[sidereal day]]), using frequency-division multiple access with right-hand circularly polarized carriers at G1 = 1602.00 MHz + n · 9/16 MHz and G2 = 1246.00 MHz + n · 7/16 MHz (n = "frequency number" integer, have values 0,1,...,24 from 1982 to 1998, 0,1,...,13 from 1998 to 2005 and -7,-6,...,6 after 2005; G2 is 7/9 of G1) currently using [[GLONASS time]] as the time standard and [[PZ-90]] as the spatial reference ellipsoid frame. The public user interface is defined in the [[ICD-GLONASS]]: Global Navigation Satellite System (GLONASS): Interface Control Document, Navigational radiosignal in bands L1, L2.

entry.name: GLONASS time
entry.description: <wiki> time system used by [[GLONASS]], based on the [[UTC]](SU) time frame generated by Russian organizations, referred to the Moscow Standard Time which has an offset of three hours from Greenwich time; besides differences of full hours and full [[leap second]] (which GLONASS time includes), the difference between the GPS and GLONASS time frames have been computed to differ by 20-30 microseconds

entry.name: GNSS
entry.description: "Global Navigation Satellite System"; any of, or some combination of, the operational spaceborne radionavigation systems, at this time being [[Navstar]] [[GPS]], [[GLONASS]], [[Galileo]], [[Compass]], [[SBAS]], and/or [[QZSS]]

entry.name: GPS
entry.description: "Global Positioning System"; a specific spaceborne radionavigation system financed and operated by the U.S. Department of Defense consisting of [[Navstar]] satellites, a minumum of 21 operational and 3 active in-orbit spares, arranged in six [[MEO]] orbital planes at 63° (Block I SVs) and 55° (Block II SVs) inclinations, approximately 20197 km above the Earth (orbital period of 11h 58m, or 2 orbits every 1 [[sidereal day]]), using code-division multiple access with right-hand circularly polarized L-band carriers centered at L1 = 1575.42 MHz, L2 = 1227.60 MHz (= 120/154 of L1), and L5 = 1176.45 MHz (= 115/154 of L1; L5 in test mode one Block IIR-M SV, and operational in upcoming Block IIF and Block III SVs), and currently using [[GPS time]] as the time standard and [[WGS-84]] as the spatial reference ellipsoid frame; the unclassified user interface of which is defined in the [[IS-GPS-200]]: Navstar GPS Space Segment/Navigation User Interfaces

entry.name: GPS time
entry.description: <wiki> time in seconds, skipping [[UTC]] [[leap second]], since 6.0 Jan 1980 using UTC as defined by the master clock of the U.S. Naval Observatory, UTC(USNO,MC) (see also any recent "Time and Frequency Bulletin" published by the National Institute of Standards and Technology, U.S. Department of Commerce) (see also [[GPS time of week]], [[GPS week]], [[calendar]])

entry.name: GPS time of week
entry.description: <wiki> the seconds since the beginning of a [[GPS week]]; this will not exceed 604800 even for weeks containing positive [[UTC]] [[leap second]] since [[GPS time]] skips UTC leap seconds

entry.name: GPS week
entry.description: <wiki> complete weeks, skipping [[UTC]] [[leap second]], since 6.0 Jan 1980; e.g. week starting Sunday 6 Jan 1980 was GPS week 0, week starting Sunday 13 Jan 1980 was GPS week 1, and so on; only 10 bits are used to represent the GPS week modulo 1024 in the broadcast navigation messages from the [[GPS]] [[SV]], leading to a modulo 1024 rollover problem on 22.0 Aug 1999 (GPS week 1024), 7.0 Apr 2019 (GPS week 2048), 21.0 Nov 2038 (GPS week 3072), and so on (see also [[calendar]])

entry.name: group
entry.description: or data group; the top level of organization of [[data]] at the UNAVCO Boulder Facility Archive, each group being made up of data from probably from one or more [[project]]; usually a group is related on a one-to-one basis to a [[campaign]] a [[network]] of [[permanent station]], or a single field support effort for multiple regional [[project]]; subdivision of the group is by [[data set]]; storage of removable [[media]], [[log sheet]], etc. in the [[Physical Repository]] is by [[group ID]] number

entry.name: group ID
entry.description: <wiki> for the purposes of the UNAVCO Archive, a unique number specifying a specific [[group]]

entry.name: GSAC
entry.description: "GPS Seamless Archive Center"; participant in the Seamless Archive initiative promoted as an activity for the [[UNAVCO]] community by NSF; see also GSAC overview and GSAC-WS overview

entry.name: Hatanaka compression/decompression
entry.description: a compression/decompression scheme of a [[RINEX]] observation file into a smaller ASCII format used by the [[IGS]]. The Hatanaka-compressed ASCII format version of a RINEX observation file is frequently used in conjuction with the UNIX compress, zip, gzip or other generalized compression utilities to create a very small file for Internet transfer. (see also Hatanaka Format Information at UNAVCO)

entry.name: ICD-GLONASS
entry.description:
the public "interface specification" document for [[GLONASS]]; see:
  • version 5.1 (2008)
  • version 5.0 (2002)

entry.name: IERS
entry.description:
"International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service"; see also:
  • IERS Central Bureau homepage
  • IERS Publications: Messages, Bulletins, Technical Notes, Annual Reports

entry.name: IGS
entry.description:
"International GNSS Service", formally the "International GPS Service (for Geodynamics)"; a voluntary federation of more than 200 worldwide agencies that pool resources and permanent [[GNSS]] station data to generate precise GNSS products, established by the International Association of Geodesy (IAG) to aid high-precision geodetic positioning by providing phase and pseudorange [[RINEX]] [[data]] from [[permanent station]] around the world, high-precision orbits for all tracked GNSS satellites (~20 cm or better in accuracy), earth rotation parameters, etc.; Central Bureau of IGS at igscbigscb.jpl.nasa.gov; also see:
  • IGS Central Bureau homepage
  • IGS FAQs
  • IGS Data and Products
  • IGSMail Archives
  • GeoForschungsZentrum (GFZ) summary of the last 100 days of IGS sites
and text documentation:
  • IGS antenna and receiver designations for RINEX

entry.name: IGS log
entry.description:
a combination [[site]] and [[visit]] history [[log]] developed by the [[IGS]] for recording [[permanent station]] [[metadata]] in an ASCII format; see:
  • IGS site log instructions
  • blank IGS site log

entry.name: inspection
entry.description: <wiki> going to a [[setup]]/[[station]] for the purpose of checking equipment, general maintainance, etc. without modifying any of the setup (see also [[visit]])

entry.name: International Atomic Time
entry.description: <wiki> see [[TIA]]

entry.name: IONEX
entry.description:
"Ionosphere map Exchange"; ASCII exchange representation of 2- and 3-dimensional [[TEC]]-value maps given in a geographic grid; see also
  • IONEX: The IONosphere Map EXchange
  • differential code biases (DCB)

entry.name: IS-GPS-200
entry.description:
the unclassified "interface specification" document for the [[Navstar]] [[GPS]] Space Segment/Navigation User Interfaces; see:
  • GPS Public Interface Control Documents
  • IS-GPS-200, Rev. E (8 Jun 2010) (PDF — 1.5 Mb)
and related:
  • IS-GPS-705A (8 Jun 2010) User Segement L5 Interfaces (PDF — 1.2 Mb)
  • IS-GPS-800A (8 Jun 2010) User Segement L1C Interfaces (PDF — 0.8 Mb)

entry.name: IS-QZSS
entry.description:
the public "interface specification" document for [[QZSS]]; see:
  • version 1.1 (31 July 2009)
  • version 1.2 (draft) (19 March 2010)

entry.name: ITRF
entry.description:
"International Terrestrial Reference Frame"; a specific realization of the International Terrestrial Reference System (ITRS), produced by the [[IERS]] ITRS Centre; see details for specific frames: 
ITRF2008
ITRF2005
ITRF2000
ITRF(19)97
ITRF(19)96
ITRF(19)94
ITRF(19)93
ITRF(19)92
and realizations ITRF(19)89, ITRF(19)90, ITRF(19)91, and ITRF(19)95 (see also [[WGS-84]], [[PZ-90]])

entry.name: Julian date
entry.description: solar days since 1.5 Universal Time (i.e. noon on the 1st) Jan 4713 BCE (on the proleptic Julian calendar); the start of [[GPS time]] (i.e. GPS standard epoch) 6.0 Jan 1980 is exactly equivalent to Julian date 2444244.5 (i.e. GPS time and [[UTC]] were essentially the same (to ±1 microsecond) from 6.0 Jan 1980 to 1.0 Jul 1981 when the first UTC [[leap second]] offset was introduced during GPS time at the end of 30 Jun 1981); compare with [[modified Julian date]]; see also U.S. Naval Observatory's Julian Date Converter

entry.name: Julian day
entry.description: <wiki> same as [[Julian date]], though sometimes incorrectly used to refer to the [[day-of-year]] or ordinal date of the year

entry.name: LAAS
entry.description: "Local Area Agmentation System", being developed by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in the USA; see LAAS Program

entry.name: lcode
entry.description: <wiki> "location code"; a lexically-sortable, non-unique, case-insensitive, 6-character alphanumeric string which geographically locates a Earth-based surface [[monument]] to at least a 100m x 100m square on the Earth

entry.name: LDM
entry.description:
"Local Data Manager"; product of UCAR's Unidata group that allows secure pushing and/or pulling of files between two nodes of a TCP/IP network; establishing LDM on a group of nodes allows the establishment of a secure data flow topology; see also:
  • Unidata's LDM homepage

entry.name: leap second
entry.description:
second added (or subtracted) to keep the [[UTC]] time scale within ±0.9 second of the [[UT1]] time scale, which changes due to changes in the rotation rate of the Earth; since the introduction of leap seconds into UTC (with the first on 1972 Jun 30), only positive leap seconds have been included which begin at 23 h 59 min 60 s UTC and end at 0 h 0 min 0 s UTC demarking the beginning of the next day; positive leap seconds since the beginning of [[GPS time]] have been inserted at the end of:
    1981 Jun 30
    1982 Jun 30
    1983 Jun 30
    1985 Jun 30
    1987 Dec 31
    1989 Dec 31
    1990 Dec 31
    1992 Jun 30
    1993 Jun 30
    1994 Jun 30
    1995 Dec 31
    1997 Jun 30
    1998 Dec 31
    2005 Dec 31
    2008 Dec 31
so, between 1.0 Jan 1999 UTC and 1.0 Jan 2006 UTC, GPS - 13 seconds = UTC; between 1.0 Jan 2006 UTC and 1.0 Jan 2009 UTC, GPS - 14 seconds = UTC; and as of 1.0 Jan 2009 UTC (and before the next leap second is inserted), GPS - 15 seconds = UTC. See NIST Time Scale Data Archive for the latest leap second listing (updated monthly); see USNO EO Database Search to obtain a daily listing of UT1-UTC (observed and/or predicted); see also USNO leap second page for more background. Note: A positive leap second was inserted at the end of December 2008.

The leap second: its history and possible future, Nelson et al., Metrologia, 38, 509-529, 2001.

Articles discussing the lack of leap seconds between the end of 1998 and the end of 2005:
  • Goddard Space Flight Center Top Story: Satellites reveal a mystery of large change in Earth's gravity field
  • National Geographic News: Why is Earth's Girth Bulging?

entry.name: LEO
entry.description: "Low Earth Orbit"; any orbit with an orbital period of less than about two hours

entry.name: log
entry.description: <wiki> documentation of a [[site]] description and/or a [[visit]] (see also [[form]])

entry.name: log file
entry.description: <wiki> electronic version of a [[log sheet]], e.g. an on-line [[IGS]] [[site]] log

entry.name: log sheet
entry.description: <wiki> a blank or filled-in [[log]] on paper

entry.name: magnetic declination
entry.description:
offset between the direction of true geographic north and the local direction of magnetic north; see NOAA/NGDC's geomagnetic calculators:
  • magnetic declination + rate
  • 3-d magnetic field orientation + rate
  • current field grid, 1 of 7 parameters

entry.name: marker
entry.description: <wiki> if it exists, an identifiable and distinct component of a [[monument]] having a [[survey point]], e.g. a USGS brass cap

entry.name: media
entry.description: or physical media; best explained by example: 9-track, QIC (1/4" cartridge tape), audio cassette tape, 3.5" or 5.25" floppy disk, 4mm DAT, 8mm data tape, 8mm video tape, optical disk, magneto-optical disk, PC-Card (PCMCIA), Zip disk, Jazz disk, CD-R, CD-ROM, hard disk, etc.

entry.name: MEO
entry.description: "Medium Earth Orbit"; any orbit with an orbital period of about two to sixteen hours

entry.name: metadata
entry.description: <wiki> ancillary information required for the accurate processing of observation and navigation [[data]] to determine the position, velocity, and/or acceleration of a single or set of [[survey point]]; e.g. [[antenna]] [[phase center]] position relative to a survey point (if no horizontal offset, this is just the "antenna height"), antenna type, receiver type, approximate [[WGS-84]] coordinates, etc.; most of the information in a [[RINEX]] file header is metadata

entry.name: MJD
entry.description: "modified Julian date"; see [[modified Julian date]] for definition

entry.name: modified Julian date
entry.description: <wiki> an offset version of the [[Julian date]] obtained by subtracting 2400000.5 days from the Julian date; thus the start of [[GPS time]] (i.e. GPS standard epoch) 6.0 Jan 1980 is equivalent to a modified Julian date of 44244.0

entry.name: monument
entry.description: <wiki> a physical object for which one is trying to collect [[data]] for a determination of position, velocity, and/or acceleration for one or more [[survey point]] on or very near that object. (In the case of a zero offset for the antenna, the survey point of measurement is the [[phase center]] of the antenna, which may or may not actually correspond to a physical point on the object.) (see also [[lcode]], [[marker]], [[monument code]], [[monument ID]], [[monument name]], [[monument setting]], [[site]])

entry.name: monument code
entry.description: a non-unique, case-insensitive, 4-character alphanumeric string to identify a specific [[survey point]] on a specific [[monument]], e.g. "PEAK" = "peak"; also known as the [[4-char ID]] of a survey point of a monument, obtained from the monument record form or something similar

entry.name: monument ID
entry.description: <wiki> for the internal purposes of the UNAVCO Archive, a unique number specifying a specific [[survey point]] on a specific [[monument]]; if multiple survey points are used on a single monument, then multiple monument IDs would be assigned corresponding to each survey point used

entry.name: monument name
entry.description: a (hopefully) descriptive name for a particular [[monument]]; a 60-character version of which could be used in the [[RINEX]] Observation file for the non-optional MARKER NAME field

entry.name: monument setting
entry.description: <wiki> a date stamp associated with a [[monument]] or a [[marker]] on a monument indicating either 1) when the monument was established, or if that time is not known 2) when the monument was first known to be used

entry.name: Navstar
entry.description: "Navigation Satellite Timing And Ranging"; the official name of the [[GPS]] satellites, e.g. see NASA SPACEWARN Bulletin No. 653 describing Navstar 62 launched in March 2008

entry.name: network
entry.description: <wiki> an array of [[GNSS]] [[setup]] and/or [[station]] operating at the same time for the purpose of collecting more or less [[continuous data]] over the extent of the array; the spatial extent of the array can be global or anything smaller

entry.name: observable
entry.description: <wiki> any measurement between the space segment and the user segment of the [[GPS]], [[GLONASS]], [[Galileo]] or [[SBAS]], e.g. [[receiver]] clock [[epoch]] time, and at the epoch: carrier-phase (L1 or L2) measurements, pseudorange or code (C/A, P1, or P2) measurements, doppler measurements of L1 or L2, [[signal]]-to-noise measurements, etc.

entry.name: observation
entry.description: <wiki> a set of carrier-phase and/or pseudorange [[observable]] for an individual [[Navstar]] [[GPS]], [[GLONASS]], [[Galileo]] or [[SBAS]] [[SV]] for a specific [[epoch]]

entry.name: occupation
entry.description: <wiki> a [[visit]] (depending on whether you prefer a militaristic or pacific term)

entry.name: off-site
entry.description: <wiki> someplace other than the [[site]]

entry.name: ordinal date
entry.description: <wiki> same as [[day-of-year]]

entry.name: On-line Repository
entry.description: <wiki> dedicated electronic RAID storage of archived [[data file]] at the UNAVCO Boulder Facility Archive

entry.name: OS SIS ICD
entry.description:
the unclassified "interface specification" document for the [[Galileo]] Open Service Signal-In-Space Interface Control Document; see:
  • OS SIS ICD (1 Feb 2010) (PDF — 3.8 Mb)

entry.name: PANGA
entry.description:
"Pacific Northwest Geodetic Array"; see also:
  • PANGA, Central Washington University homepage
  • University of Washington GPS Geodesy homepage, including PANGA

entry.name: PBO
entry.description: "Plate Boundary Observatory"; one of the main components of [[EarthScope]], this is a set of surface (GPS [[permanent station]]) and subsurface (strainmeters) to measure the crustal motion and deformation in the plate boundary between the North American and Pacific plates in the western USA and Alaska; see also EarthScope & PBO

entry.name: permanent station
entry.description:
<wiki>
very long-term [[setup]] at a [[continuous site]];
implies long-term power and possibly other infrastructure such as communication

entry.name: permanent station data
entry.description: <wiki> [[data]] from one or more [[permanent station]]

entry.name: phase center
entry.description: <wiki> relative to the active [[antenna]] element and ground plane, where a specific carrier-phase frequency from [[GNSS]] [[SV]] seem to be received; the phase center may be modeled as averaged over all possible directions, modeled as a function of elevation from the ground plane, or even modeled as a function of elevation and azimuth (see [[phase center pattern]])

entry.name: phase center pattern
entry.description:
the elevation and azimuthal offset of the effective [[phase center]] of the [[antenna]]; see also
  • GPS antenna calibrations by the staff of the Instrumentation and Methodologies Branch, Geodetic Services Division, National Geodetic Survey, NOAA, Dept. of Commerce
  • igs_01.pcv: IGS antenna phase center offsets and variations
  • UNAVCO ARI antenna calibration report

entry.name: Physical Repository
entry.description: <wiki> dedicated storage room(s) for physical [[media]], [[log sheet]], etc. at the UNAVCO Boulder Facility Archive, organized by [[group]] ID number

entry.name: principal investigator
entry.description: <wiki> the big cheese/head honcho/primary cognizant entity associated with a [[project]]

entry.name: PRN
entry.description:
"Pseudo-Random Noise" (or sometimes Number); an integer sequence number, 1-32, assigned to each of the [[Navstar]] [[GPS]] [[SV]] to indicate its own unique C/A-code and its own unique P-code; this is the GPS SV number that is used in a [[RINEX]] observation or navigation file that is used to distinguish each satellite

PRN numbers 33 – 37 are reserved for other uses, such as ground transmitters

PRN numbers 38 – 63 are reserved for future GPS SVs

PRN numbers of 64 – 119 are reserved for future [[GBAS]] amd other augmentation systems

PRN numbers 120 – 158 are reserved for [[SBAS]]

PRN numbers 159 – 210 are reserved for other [[GNSS]] applications

entry.name: project
entry.description: proposed or realized work in one or more of the following: [[site]] reconnaissance, [[monument]] installation (or monumentation), [[permanent station]] installation, [[campaign]] or permanent station [[data]] collection

entry.name: PZ-90
entry.description:
"Parameters of the Earth 1990" (PZ-90 in Russian); formerly known as Soviet Geodetic System 1990 (SGS-90) and nearly identical to SGS-85; the [[ECEF]] spatial coordinate system used by [[GLONASS]]; the estimated transformation between SGS-85 and WGS-84 included a 4 meter offset of the z-axis and a 0.6" (3e-6 radian) rotation about the z-axis, whereas the transformation between PZ-90 and WGS-84 is only a 0.33" to 0.40" (1.6e-6 to 1.9e-6 radian) rotation about the z-axis, with perhaps a 2.5 meter offset of the y-axis; the system is defined as:
  • the origin is the center of mass of the Earth
  • z-axis is directed to the average North pole of the 1900-1905 epoch
  • x-axis is in the equator plane of the 1900-1905 epoch, the XOZ plane being parallel to the average Greenwich meridian
  • y-axis completes the system as a right-handed rectangular system
(see also [[WGS-84]], [[ITRF]])

entry.name: QZSS
entry.description:
"Quasi- Zenith Satellite System"; a specific spaceborne radionavigation system financed and operated by the Japan planned to consist of up to 18 geosynchronous satellites (mean height of approximately 35786 km above mean sea level but in a highly elliptical orbit, with an orbital period of 23h 56m 04.091s, or 1 orbit every [[sidereal day]]) using code-division multiple access with a right-hand circularly polarized carrier centered at L1 = 1575.42 MHz, L2 = 1227.60 MHz, L5 = 1176.45 MHz, and LEX = 1278.75 MHz; operational and proposed satellites of [[PRN]] 193 to 202 (with 203-210 as potential spares):
  • L1-SAIF performance enhancement signal on 183-192, though 188-192 are used for QZS maintenance/test purposes and must not be used by users
  • LEX performance enhancement signal on 193-202, though 198-202 are used for QZS maintenance/test purposes and must not be used by users
  • other QZSS signals on 193-202, though 198-202 are used for QZS maintenance/test purposes and must not be used by users
  • thus normal user PRNs for initial QZSS without L1-SAIF are 193-197
The public user interface is defined in the [[IS-QZSS]]: Quasi-Zenith Satellite System Navigation Service: Interface Specification for QZSS.

entry.name: radome
entry.description: <wiki> see [[antenna dome]]

entry.name: raw data
entry.description: <wiki> lowest-level, proprietary or non-proprietary [[data file]] available from a [[GNSS]] [[receiver]] containing both [[data]] and [[metadata]]; e.g. Trimble's DAT, EPH, ION, and MES [[download]] files, AOA's ConanBinary or TurboBinary files, Ashtech's B-, E-, and S-download files, etc.; usually a majority of the data and metadata in a data file is in an encoded binary format.

entry.name: raw file code
entry.description: a non-unique, case-insensitive, 4-character alphanumeric string to identify a specific [[survey point]] on a specific [[monument]], e.g. "PEAK" = "peak"; also known as the [[4-char ID]] of a survey point of a monument, obtained from the raw data file itself (see also [[monument code]] and [[visit code]])

entry.name: real-time monitoring
entry.description: <wiki> [[continuous data]] is transferred near-real-time via one or more communication paths [[off-site]] for near-real-time [[data]] collection, quality checking, and/or processing; time delay should generally be no more than a few minutes

entry.name: receiver
entry.description: <wiki> device used to decode the digital and analog components of the [[GNSS]] [[signal]] supplied by the [[antenna]], as specified in part by the [[IS-GPS-200]] for [[GPS]], or the analog for [[GLONASS]], [[Galileo]] or [[SBAS]]

entry.name: reference point
entry.description: <wiki> a special case of a [[survey point]] usually used to locate a primary survey point or serve as a backup to a primary survey point especially in cases where the primary survey point has been lost or destroyed

entry.name: RINEX
entry.description:
"Receiver Independent Exchange"; ASCII exchange representation of [[GNSS]] [[data]] and [[metadata]] currently conforming to the specification given in "RINEX: The Receiver Independent Exchange Format Version 2(.xx)" available from the Astronomical Institute, University of Berne (AIUB); one of several general file types:
  • RINEX observation (OBS) file
  • RINEX navigation (NAV) file (e.g. for [[GPS]], [[GLONASS]], and [[SBAS]])
  • RINEX meteorological (MET) file
  • RINEX clock (CLK) file
also see documentation:
  • RINEX documentation listing at IGS Central Bureau
  • RINEX Ver. 2(.00) (Apr 1993)
  • RINEX Ver. 2.10 (10 Dec 2007)
  • RINEX SBAS NAV Ver. 2.10 (19 Dec 2003)
  • RINEX Ver. 2.11 (10 Dec 2007)
  • RINEX Ver. 2.12 (22 Jun 2009)
  • RINEX Ver. 3.00 (latest: 28 Nov 2007)
  • RINEX Ver. 3.01 (22 Jun 2009)
and related:
  • IONEX Ver. 1.00 (25 Feb 1998)
  • Earth Rotation Parameters Ver. 2 (10 Jul 1998)
  • Clock Ver. 3.00 (14 Nov 2006)
  • Clock Ver. 3.02 (02 Sep 2010)
and see
  • IGS antenna and receiver designations for RINEX, available at JPL's IGS Central Bureau ftp site; these RINEX entries for receiver and antenna types are not part of the RINEX specification, but, rather, represent an effort by the [[IGS]] to standardize the ASCII strings used to describe various common receiver and antenna types and are widely accepted

entry.name: RTCM
entry.description: "Radio Technical Commission Maritime Services"; for example, RTCM Special Committee 104 (SC-104) recommends standards for differential [[GPS]]/[[GNSS]] [[data]] exchange

entry.name: SBAS
entry.description:
"Satellite Based Agmentation System"; the component of a set of geostationary satellites (one orbital plane at 0° inclination, approximately 35786 km above mean sea level at the equator, with an orbital period of 23h 56m 04.091s, or 1 orbit every [[sidereal day]]) to augment [[GNSS]] use for civilian applications using code-division multiple access with a right-hand circularly polarized carrier centered at L1 = 1575.42 MHz and a (proposed) L5 = 1176.45 MHz; the operational and proposed satellites of [[PRN]] 120 to 138 include:
  • WAAS (Wide-Area Augmentation System) for the USA and Canadian area
  • CWAAS (Canadian WAAS)
  • EGNOS (European Geostationary Navigation Overlay Service) a joint project of the European Space Agency (ESA), the European Commission (EC) and Eurocontrol, the European Organisation for the Safety of Air Navigation for the European area
  • MSAS (MTSAT-Based Augmentation System) Japan MTSAT (Multi-functional Transport Satellite)
  • GAGAN (Indian GPS And GEO Augmented Navigation)
  • SNAS (Chinese Satellite Navigation and Augmentation Service)
where the current operational or proposed satellites are:

Inmarsat 3 F2, AOR-E 15.33°W PRN 120 EGNOS
Inmarsat 3 F4, AOR-W 53.98°W PRN 122 WAAS
ESA Artemis 21.67°E PRN 124 EGNOS
Inmarsat 3 F5, IND-W 25.06°E PRN 126 EGNOS
Inmarsat 4 F1 143.61°E PRN 127 GAGAN
Insat-NAV (tbd) PRN 128 GAGAN
MTSAT-1R 140.17°E PRN 129 MSAS
Inmarsat 3 F1, IOR 65.5°E PRN 131 EGNOS
Inmarsat 3 F3, POR 178.06°E PRN 134 WAAS
PanAmSat Galaxy XV 132.87°W PRN 135 WAAS
MTSAT-2 144.75°E PRN 137 MSAS
Telesat Anik F1R 107.17°W PRN 138 WAAS
see also:
  • SX Blue GPS: SBAS Resources
  • GPS World: Innovation: The WAAS L65 Signal
  • Satellite Based Augmentation System
  • C-Nav LBand Communication Satellite Locator

entry.name: SCEC
entry.description:
"Southern California Earthquake Center"; see also [[SCIGN]] and:
  • SCEC homepage

entry.name: SCIGN
entry.description:
"Southern California Integrated GPS Network"; see also:
  • SCIGN homepage

entry.name: session
entry.description: <wiki> a pre-definable time during which a [[GNSS]] [[receiver]] will record [[observation]] according to some pre-defined parameters, such as sample interval or [[data format]]

entry.name: semi-continuous site
entry.description: <wiki> a [[site]] with a [[continuous station]] that has significant [[data]] gaps by design, for example so that the equipment can be moved to another similar site

entry.name: semi-continuous site data
entry.description: <wiki> [[data]] from one or more [[semi-continuous site]]

entry.name: setting
entry.description: <wiki> [[monument setting]]

entry.name: setup
entry.description: <wiki> (not necessarily limited to): the [[antenna dome]], the [[antenna]], antenna's LNA (low-noise amplifier), the [[choke ring]] (if any), tripod or other antenna support, [[antenna cable]], in-line surge suppressor (if any), [[receiver]], receiver firmware, (and any other item in the [[signal]] path) established around a [[monument]] for the purpose of collecting [[GNSS]] [[data]]; modification of anything (see the above items, or a change in antenna height) that could effect positioning results constitutes a new setup (see also [[station]], [[visit]])

entry.name: sidereal day
entry.description: <wiki> time for the Earth to rotation 360° on its axis; 23h 56m 4.091s

entry.name: signal
entry.description: <wiki> both the analog and binary components of the electromagnetic radiation emitted by either the [[Navstar]] [[GPS]], [[GLONASS]], [[Galileo]], or [[SBAS]] space segments; the signal is centered at one or more microwave frequencies

entry.name: SINEX
entry.description:
"Solution Independent Exchange": see specification for 2.00 (24 May 2002) and 2.01 (25 Mar 2005):
  • IERS SINEX format links

entry.name: site
entry.description:
the general, immediate area around one or more monuments or where one or more monuments may be installed
    A site is the top layer in a hierarchy (after monument installation):
       a site has one or more [[monument]],
       a monument has zero or more [[marker]],
       a marker has one or more [[survey point]].
If a physical marker is not part of a particular monument, that monument still must have at least one identifiable survey point. The equipment to collect [[GNSS]] [[data]] at a particular survey point is either a [[setup]] or a [[station]].

entry.name: site description
entry.description: <wiki> the general description of a [[site]], primarily to identify how to find the site from surrounding towns, roads, landmarks, etc.

entry.name: smtp
entry.description: "simple mail transfer protocol"; normal [[email]] transfer protocol

entry.name: SOPAC
entry.description:
"Scripps Orbit and Permanent Array Center" of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California of San Deigo; see also:
  • SOPAC homepage

entry.name: SP3
entry.description:
"Standard Product 3" Orbit Format for [[GPS]] (also now known as SP3-a), an ASCII exchange format for representing GPS satellite orbits; see also
  • Extended Standard Product 3 Orbit Format (SP3-c)
  • original SP3 proposal

entry.name: SP3-b
entry.description: "Standard Product 3" Orbit Format for [[GPS]] and [[GLONASS]], an ASCII exchange format for representing GPS and GLONASS satellite orbits

entry.name: SP3-c
entry.description:
Extended "Standard Product 3" Orbit Format for [[GPS]] and [[GLONASS]], an ASCII exchange format for representing GPS and GLONASS satellite orbits; see also
  • Extended Standard Product 3 Orbit Format (SP3-c) (5 Sep 2002)
  • IGSMail-5008 (7 Sep 2004) Some information on the error codes given in the SP3-c

entry.name: station
entry.description:
a long-term [[setup]]; antenna support is usually more permanent than just a tripod; a station probably includes the setup plus power, communication, and/or other infrastructure

Setup and station imply two ends of the time spectrum. A setup is generally more short-term (on the order of hours to days) and a station is more long-term (on the order of months to years). On occasion, a setup (plus long-term power) is pushed into long-term use (many months), but it still does not have the permanence and survivability implied by the term "station".

entry.name: survey point
entry.description: <wiki> a precisely definable location (down to millimeter or sub-millimeter levels) to which an [[antenna]] is located for the purpose of receiving [[GNSS]] [[signal]]; this may be a physical point such a dimple or cross-hair intersection on a [[marker]], or may a virtual (non-physical) point (see also [[marker]], [[monument]], [[site]])

entry.name: survey mark
entry.description: <wiki> in our terminology the same as [[survey point]]

entry.name: SV
entry.description: "Space Vehicle", referring originally to a specific [[Navstar]] [[GPS]] satellite, but now used to refer to any one of the Navstar GPS, [[GLONASS]], [[Galileo]], or [[SBAS]] satellites

entry.name: TEC
entry.description: "total electron count" of the ionosphere, which dominates the ionospheric refraction

entry.name: teqc
entry.description:
"translate, edit, and quality check" software, a UNAVCO Boulder Facility data/metadata toolkit; see also
  • teqc homepage

entry.name: TIA
entry.description: <wiki> "Temps Atomique International" or "International Atomic Time", based on the weighted average of a large number of atomic clocks, where since 1967 the second is defined as the period of time equal to 9192631770 cycles of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine energy levels of the ground state of the cesium-133 atom (Cs-133); available since 1955, but TIA was defined as being equal [[UT1]] at the epoch 1.0 Jan 1958

entry.name: TRANSIT
entry.description: <wiki> full name of Navy Navigation Satellite System (NNSS) TRANSIT, this was the immediate predecessor of the [[Navstar]] [[GPS]] system; a specific spaceborne radionavigation system financed and operated by the U.S. Department of Defense consisting of 6-10 satellites (3-5 providing navigation service and 3-5 acting as in-orbit spares) in near-circular [[LEO]] polar orbits approximately 1075 km above the Earth (orbital period of 1h 46m, or about 27 orbits every 2 [[sidereal day]]) transmitting phase modulated navigation signals at 0.150 and 0.400 GHz; any signals after 31 Dec 1996 should not be used for timing or position; used [[WGS-72]] until 27 Jan 1989 as its [[ECEF]] spatial coordinate system, whereupon this was switched to [[WGS-84]]

entry.name: UNAVCO
entry.description:
"University Navstar Consortium" up until 30 Sept 2003, after which UNAVCO is just a name (i.e. not an acronym) representing the non-profit membership-governed organization that supports and promotes Earth science by advancing high-precision geodetic and strain techniques and technologies such as the [[GPS]]; see also:
  • UNAVCO, Inc. homepage
  • UNAVCO Boulder Facility homepage

entry.name: UNIX epoch
entry.description: <wiki> time base for UNIX operating systems, based on the number on non-leap seconds since 1.0 Jan 1970 [[UTC]]; many current systems store the UNIX time internally as a 4-byte 2's complement integer, so that the maximum number of seconds that can be dealt with is 2^31 - 1 = 2147483647, equivalent to 2038 Jan 19 03:14:07 -- though any potential problem with this end date will probably be dealt with long before it's reached (probably by switching to a 8-byte 2's complement integer)

entry.name: Universal Time
entry.description: <wiki> see definitions for the various realizations: [[UT0]], [[UT1]], [[UT2]], and [[UTC]]

entry.name: UT0
entry.description: <wiki> Universal Time base defined as precise solar time at the zero meridian (Greenwich)

entry.name: UT1
entry.description: <wiki> [[UT0]] corrected for the Earth's polar motion

entry.name: UT2
entry.description: <wiki> [[UT1]] corrected for seasonal variations in the Earth's rotation rate

entry.name: UTC
entry.description:
not an acronym, but "Coordinated Universal Time", a hydrid time scale defined where the rate of UTC is based on atomic frequency standards (currently using [[TIA]]) but the epoch of UTC is synchronized to be within ±0.9 sec of [[UT1]]; this synchronization was defined as UTC = TIA - 10 seconds on 1.0 Jan 1972, and further synchronized since then by the insertion of [[leap second]]; some of the various realizations of UTC being:
  • UTC(USNO) — U.S. Naval Observatory (Washington D.C., USA)
  • UTC(GPS) — [[GPS time]] automatically steered to UTC(USNO) on a daily basis to keep system time within ±1 microsecond of UTC(USNO)
  • UTC(NIST) — National Institute of Standards and Technology (Boulder, Colorado, USA)
  • UTC(NPL) — National Physical Laboratory (Middlesex, UK)
  • UTC(PTB) — Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (Braunschweig, Germany)
  • UTC(BIPM) — Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (Sèvres, France)
  • UTC(SU) — (Vniftrii, Russia)
  • UTC(CRL) — Communications Research Laboratory (Koganei/Tokyo, Japan)
  • UTC(Europe Lab)
and see listings of the delta between standardized UTC and various realizations

entry.name: visit
entry.description: also site visit; establishing a [[setup]]/[[station]] at a [[monument]] for the purpose of collecting [[data]]; the UNAVCO Data Group maintains a GPS site visit [[form]] to be filled out for each visit, the information on which corresponds to the visit table in the [[Archive Database]]; if something about a [[setup]] changes during data collection (for example a change of receiver, receiver firmware, antenna, antenna height, etc.), the earlier visit ends and a new visit begins at the time of the change (see also [[inspection]], [[occupation]])

entry.name: visit code
entry.description: a non-unique, case-insensitive, 4-character alphanumeric string to identify a specific [[survey point]] on a specific [[monument]], e.g. "PEAK" = "peak"; also known as the [[4-char ID]] of a survey point of a monument, usually the same as the [[monument code]], obtained from the survey log — monument visit logsheet, monument record logsheet, or something similar

entry.name: visit ID
entry.description: <wiki> for the purposes of the UNAVCO Archive, a unique number specifying a specific [[visit]]

entry.name: WGS-72
entry.description:
"World Geodetic System 1972"; the spatial coordinate system used by [[GPS]] through 21 Jan 1987 (see also [[WGS-84]]) Some of the major constants in WGS-72, which models the Earth as an ellipsoid of revolution, are:
  • semimajor axis (origin to equator on x-y plane) = 6378.135 km
  • semiminor axis (origin to either pole) = 6356.7505 km
  • flattening = 1/298.26
  • angular velocity of Earth = 7.292115147e-5 radians/s
  • G x mass of Earth = 3.986008e14 m**3/s**2

entry.name: WGS-84
entry.description:
"World Geodetic System 1984"; the [[ECEF]] spatial coordinate system used by [[GPS]] since 22 Jan 1987 (see, for example, "Session 2: World Geodetic System 1984" pp. 67-134, in Proceedings of the Fourth International Geodetic Symposium on Satellite Positioning, Apr. 28 - May 2, 1986, Volume 1); defined in the [[IS-GPS-200]] as:
  • origin is the center of mass of the Earth
  • z-axis is parallel to the direction of the Conventional International Origin (CIO) as defined by the Bureau International de'l Heure (BIH), and passes through instantaneous pole of epoch 1984.0
  • x-axis is the intersection of the reference meridian plane and the plane of the mean astronomic equator, with the reference meridian being parallel to the zero meridian defined by the BIH
  • y-axis completes the system as a right-handed rectangular system
Some of the major constants in WGS-84, which models the Earth as an ellipsoid of revolution, are:
  • semimajor axis (origin to equator on x-y plane) = 6378.137 km
  • semiminor axis (origin to either pole) = 6356.7523142 km
  • flattening = 1/298.257223563
  • angular velocity of Earth = 7.292115e-5 radians/s
  • angular velocity of Earth (untruncated) = 7.2921151467e-5 radians/s
    (for precise satellite applications)
  • G x mass of Earth = 3.986005e14 m**3/s**2
(see also [[ITRF]], [[PZ-90]])
